text:
New Zealand national cricket team ace speedster Matt Henry was ruled off the ICC Champions Trophy 2025 grand finale against the India national cricket team at the Dubai International Cricket Stadium in Dubai on Sunday. Matt Henry sustained a shoulder injury during the Champions Trophy 2025 Semi-Final clash against the South Africa national cricket team on March 5 in Lahore. New Zealand named Nathan Smith as Matt Henry's replacement in their playing XI for the high-voltage final against the Rohit Sharma-led India. Matt Henry Ruled Out of IND vs NZ ICC Champions Trophy 2025 Final With Shoulder Injury, Nathan Smith Replaces Injured Kiwi Pacer In CT 2025 Summit Clash.
Nathan Smith's consistent performances in the domestic circuit have earned him a spot in the national side. He has bagged many wickets across formats in domestic cricket. The right-arm speedster has made his debut for the New Zealand national cricket team in the Test and ODI format. Nathan Smith is known for his great line and lengths and can trouble batters with his pace. In this article, take a look at some interesting facts about the New Zealand star pacer.
Quick Facts About New Zealand's Nathan Smith
Nathan Gregory Smith, also known as Nathan Smith, was born on July 15, 1998, in Dunedin, Otago, New Zealand.
Nathan Smith earned a bachelor's degree in commerce from Massey University with a major in accounting and management.
Nathan Smith's consistent performance in age group cricket helped him to earn a spot in the New Zealand 2016 U-19 World Cup. He finished as New Zealand's highest wicket-taker.
The 26-year-old Nathan Smith made his Test debut against the England national cricket team at Christchurch in November 2024.
The right-arm speedster made his ODI debut against the Sri Lanka national cricket team in Dambulla in November 2024. Which Team Nathan Smith is Part of in IPL 2025? Know Details About Which Franchise Young Kiwi Pacer Will Play for in Indian Premier League Season 18.
In 55 First-Class matches, Nathan Smith has bagged 151 wickets at a good average of 26.90. In List A cricket, the star speedster has taken 65 wickets. Nathan Smith has scalped 67 wickets in 63 T20s till now.
The 26-year-old cricketer was also named New Zealand Menâ€™s Domestic Player of the Year in March 2024.
Nathan Smith's valuable contribution with the bat has helped him to become an integral member of any side he plays. His all-round abilities will help the New Zealand national cricket team. Given his consistent rise in cricket, it's only a matter of time before Nathan Smith becomes an important member of his nation.
(The above story first appeared on LatestLY on Mar 09, 2025 05:23 PM IST. For more news and updates on politics, world, sports, entertainment and lifestyle, log on to our website latestly.com).
title: Nathan Smith Quick Facts: Hereâ€™s All You Need To Know About Bowler Who Replaced Injured Matt Henry in New Zealand Playing XI for IND vs NZ ICC Champions Trophy 2025 Final

text:
President Donald Trump says there is an easy way for manufacturers to avoid his blizzard of tariffs: Move back to the United States. If it works, Trumpâ€™s tariff-first strategy could end a long stagnation in U.S. manufacturing output and create the kind of jobs that his blue-collar supporters crave.

â€œWhat they have to do is build their car plants, frankly, and other things, in the United States, in which case they have no tariffs,â€ the president said last week.

But in trying to repatriate manufacturing, Trump is battling powerful long-term forces that have caused factory jobs to dwindle to the smallest share of U.S. employment since government records began in 1939. Just 8 percent of American workers now toil in factories, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Advertisement

Trumpâ€™s policies also work at cross-purposes. The steel and aluminum tariffs that take effect on Wednesday, for example, will mean higher costs for automakers and appliance manufacturers that use those metals. His plans for mass deportations of migrants will make it harder to find new factory workers, with the economy already operating at full employment.

Even if Trump succeeds in luring companies inside his tariff walls, it is unlikely he could regain the nearly 5 million factory jobs that have vanished since the late 1990s, according to many economists.

Machines greatly outnumber workers in modern factories. The jobs that remain require higher skills and no longer pay more than other opportunities available to workers without a college degree. Trumpâ€™s trade policy, against all odds, is trying to re-create an economy â€” and a way of life â€” that hasnâ€™t really existed in the United States for decades.

Advertisement

â€œTariffs by themselves canâ€™t be a solution,â€ said Robert Lawrence, a professor of international trade and investment at Harvard Universityâ€™s Kennedy School of Government.

Trump has long attacked the global economy as fundamentally unfair. Foreign nations, he insists, take advantage of the United States through unbalanced trade deals even as Washington provides a defense umbrella for them.

Relocating the auto plants, furniture factories and other workshops that moved offshore during an era of hyper-globalization is the presidentâ€™s answer to a chronic U.S. trade deficit that topped $1.2 trillion last year, a record.

The presidentâ€™s goal is â€œto rebalance the international economic system,â€ Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said in a speech Thursday. Global trade is distorted by countries such as China that suppress consumer demand and rely on export sales to keep their factories busy, he said.

Advertisement

Subsidized Chinese factories churn out products at prices that American producers often cannot match, leading to a mammoth U.S. trade deficit and starving American factories of orders and jobs.

â€œThis system is not sustainable,â€ Bessent told the Economic Club of New York.

The administration is reorienting U.S. trade policy. Instead of trying to provide what Bessent called â€œcheap goodsâ€ for consumers, the administration prioritizes creating good manufacturing jobs for workers.

That could prove a tough lift.

Manufacturing employment peaked in the disco-era summer of 1979 at 19.5 million jobs. Over the next 20 years, roughly 2 million of them disappeared as automation allowed fewer workers to produce more goods. Then, amid Chinaâ€™s economic rise and entry into the global trading system, manufacturing employment plunged by almost 6 million jobs between 1998 and 2010.

Advertisement

In his first term as president, Trump made limited progress reviving the nationâ€™s factories by imposing tariffs on roughly two-thirds of what Americans bought from China.

Manufacturing employment rose by a modest 411,000 jobs between his inauguration and early 2020, on the eve of the pandemic.

His successor, President Joe Biden, tried to use industrial policy â€” a blend of tax incentives and subsidies â€” to spark a manufacturing revival. Companies more than tripled their spending on the construction of new factories. But the employment gains were muted. Manufacturing jobs peaked at 12.9 million in early 2023, just 110,000 above Trumpâ€™s first-term peak.

Tariff supporters say a greater emphasis on manufacturing is essential for both strong communities and a strong defense, citing the experience of an earlier period.

Advertisement

From 1950 until the early 1980s, the U.S. current account, the broadest measure of the nationâ€™s trade balance, was usually in surplus. The last 40 years, however, have seen a chronic deficit that many analysts blame for the hollowing-out of manufacturing-dependent communities.

â€œWeâ€™ve been rowing in the wrong direction on trade and industrial policy for 30 or 40 years. And no, itâ€™s not going to change overnight. But thatâ€™s not an excuse to do nothing,â€ said Mark DiPlacido, a policy adviser with American Compass, a conservative group.

Where mainstream economists see global integration as the most efficient way of producing the goods and services that Americans demand, the president has said â€œwe donâ€™t needâ€ what our trading partners sell us. Rather than buy Canadian lumber or oil, Trump prefers American alternatives.

Advertisement

â€œWe want factory production in America. We want employment to blossom in America,â€ Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick told reporters on Thursday. â€œWeâ€™re going to bring factories back to America.â€

In the best case, if enough factories returned to eliminate the trade deficit for the first time in decades, perhaps 2 million new jobs could be created, according to an estimate by Harvardâ€™s Lawrence. Thatâ€™s a significant number, though just a fraction of the total that disappeared since globalization hit high gear. And it would come at a cost.

At 1 percent of gross domestic product, the tariffs that Trump has proposed so far amount to one of the largest tax increases ever imposed, according to economist Dean Baker of the Center for Economic and Policy Research, a left-leaning think tank in Washington.

Advertisement

Bringing footloose factories back to the United States may not deliver the high-paying, blue-collar jobs that some advocates anticipate. Factory work once enjoyed a reputation for offering better pay and benefits than other jobs that did not require a college degree. But that wage premium for production workers â€œdisappearedâ€ in 2006, concluded a 2022 study by Federal Reserve economists, which said a fall in union membership accounted for most of the decline.

Still, steady jobs offering regular hours provide other benefits beyond a paycheck, according to Susan Helper, an economics professor at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland.

â€œWhen GM closed its Lordstown [Ohio] plant, one of the things people talked about was the loss of Sunday school teachers and Cub Scout pack leaders,â€ she said. â€œBecause if you worked at GM, you could have only one job and support your family. If you worked elsewhere, you had two or three jobs and had no time for civic engagement.â€

Advertisement

The presidentâ€™s on-again, off-again tariff diplomacy is not making his quest any easier. Trump first promised tariffs on Canada and Mexico in late January, delayed them for one month in early February, imposed them on Tuesday, exempted automakers from them on Wednesday and then granted both nations another month-long reprieve on Thursday.

At the end of that period, the president plans to introduce a comprehensive system of â€œreciprocalâ€ tariffs, matching the import taxes that other nations apply to U.S. goods in a move that would thoroughly upend long-standing trade norms.

â€œIf youâ€™re outside of the United States, itâ€™s going to be a little bit different,â€ Trump said Thursday.

The nonstop blitz of activity since Inauguration Day has left the producers Trump says he wants to help gasping for air and puzzled over where to invest. More than three-quarters of respondents cited â€œtrade uncertaintiesâ€ as their biggest challenge, more than twice the pre-election share, according to the latest survey by the National Association of Manufacturers.

To truly pull off a manufacturing revolution, Trump needs CEOs to change their spending habits. The shift over the past quarter-century to rely on factories outside the United States â€” and their low-wage laborers â€” left corporations with plenty of extra cash. But that money has largely gone to shareholders rather than to developing domestic manufacturing capacity.

Corporations today devote roughly 70 percent of the funds that are left over after paying expenses to repurchasing shares of their own stock and paying shareholder dividends, according to Stephen Blitz, chief U.S. economist for TS Lombard, an economic consultancy.

â€œYou have to make it less profitable to build it elsewhere. And tariffs are a way to do that. But itâ€™s a very blunt instrument,â€ Blitz said.

One problem is timing. Trump last week agreed to exempt automakers from his announced 25 percent tariffs on Canadian and Mexican goods until April 2, when he plans to announce his reciprocal tariffs. But he is also demanding that U.S. automakers begin moving production back to the United States in the next 30 days â€” an impossibly quick pace, according to supply chain specialists.

â€œYou canâ€™t just tell GM, â€˜Itâ€™s too expensive to buy headlights from China,â€™â€ Blitz said. â€œNobody makes headlights in the United States. So then all youâ€™re doing is adding cost without really giving time for an adjustment.â€

The White House, meanwhile, is taking credit for new manufacturing investments. On Thursday, Rodolphe SaadÃ©, the CEO of the French shipping line CMA CGM, appeared with Trump in the Oval Office to announce a $20 billion investment in the United States.

The president also has hailed announcements by Apple, TSMC and Honda, which he said would be opening a plant in Indiana.
title: Trumpâ€™s tariffs face long odds in bid to bring factories home

text:
The Federal Emergency Management Agency canceled most courses for a federally run school for firefighters as it evaluates its â€œprograms and spending to ensure alignmentâ€ with the Trump administrationâ€™s priorities, according to an email obtained by The Washington Post and a current FEMA official who spoke on the condition of anonymity to avoid professional retaliation.

FEMAâ€™s Friday email to instructors and students said that all in-person National Fire Academy courses were canceled effective immediately but that some virtual courses would continue. It was not immediately clear when the NFA would be able to resume classes, the official said. FEMA did not immediately respond to a request for comment Sunday.

The move comes as the Trump administration vows to make substantial cuts to the federal workforce, prompting widespread uncertainty and chaos among government employees and disrupting work at their agencies.

FEMA decided to cancel most of its courses, effective immediately

After FEMA issued its notice about NFA courses, it sent a follow-up message to instructors that said only virtual courses â€œthat do not have an instructor and no funds are involved will be held,â€ and asked instructors to cancel all future travel for the academy â€œuntil further notice.â€

Advertisement

Marc Bashoor, a former Maryland fire chief and West Virginia emergency services director, told the Associated Press that a new set of trainings were set to begin soon at the National Fire Academy. â€œPeople had made their plane and travel reservations. And all of a sudden, they get an email that â€˜Sorry, itâ€™s been canceled,â€™â€ he said.

The Maine Fire Service Institute, a department of Southern Maine Community College that trains firefighting professionals in the state, said an instructor for an NFA course had already arrived in Maine â€œwhen communication from NFA canceling funding to in-person trainings was sent out.â€

â€œWeâ€™re doing everything we can to get NFA back up and running,â€ the FEMA official told The Post, adding: â€œInternally, no one wants this.â€

The National Fire Academy trains thousands of firefighters and emergency workers each year

The National Fire Academy opened in 1974 as part of the National Fire Prevention and Control Administration, now known as the U.S. Fire Administration, which is the lead federal agency for fire data and training, particularly for state, local and tribal fire departments. According to its website, it provides free skills training to anyone with â€œsubstantial involvement in fire prevention and control, emergency medical services (EMS), or fire-related emergency management activities,â€ including firefighters, fire chiefs and first responders.

Advertisement

The academy trains about 100,000 people per year, including through online courses. In-person courses are conducted at its campus in Emmitsburg, Maryland, or offered via universities and local fire departments.

The courses that were canceled mainly affect smaller fire departments and volunteers who benefit from federally provided training, a former FEMA official told The Post, speaking on the condition of anonymity to avoid professional retaliation. The person said that although the courses did not include hands-on training, they provided lessons on leadership and hazardous materials.

Bashoor told the AP that the National Fire Academy is essential. â€œItâ€™s not a â€˜nice to have.â€™ It is the one avenue we have to bring people from all over the country to learn from and with each other,â€ he was quoted as saying.

Advertisement

Lori Moore-Merrell, a former U.S. fire administrator, agreed. â€œThe U.S. Fire Administrationâ€™s National Fire Academy is the premier professional training institution for Americaâ€™s structural, industrial, and wildland firefighters (both career and volunteers) from local, state, tribal, and federal agencies,â€ she said in an email. â€œThe NFA instructors also train arson investigators for all levels of government including ATF. It is a travesty that there is an interruption in these trainings, and no one knows for how long under the guise of â€˜evaluation to ensure alignment with administration priorities.â€™â€

Bashoor told FireRescue1, an industry publication, that he hoped the decision to cancel courses was â€œa temporary setback.â€ He said firefighting professionals should continue to train locally. â€œWe must not allow these changes to translate into chaos in our training or in our performance of duty,â€ he added.

Trump has targeted FEMA for review

Trumpâ€™s shake-up of the federal government, led by Elon Muskâ€™s U.S. DOGE Service, has already led agencies to cancel programming or lay off workers to avoid falling afoul of Trumpâ€™s executive orders.

Advertisement

In January, Trump said he wanted FEMA to â€œgo awayâ€ altogether and for states to handle the response to disasters and emergencies. He also ordered the establishment of a council to review the agencyâ€™s work and accused it of â€œpolitical biasâ€ and inefficiency.

In addition, Trump has issued a flurry of orders seeking to cut costs and regulations, as well as enact more cultural changes, including eliminating diversity, equity and inclusion programs, across the federal government.

Advertisement
title: FEMA cancels firefighter training amid uncertainty over Trump cuts
